title: Ticket #3809: condor_status should sort SlotId right
description:
The current default sort is intending do this, but it's failing to do it correctly because it's doing an alphanumeric sort on the slotid@machine string. This hasn't worked since there have existed >9 cores on a box (i.e., a loooooong time).

The sort should be on the Machine attr first and the SlotId second.

See also #3810.
remarks:
2013-Jul-24 14:34:58 by johnkn:
The slot id is a name, that happens to contain a number when the default name is used. it's being sorted correctly.

2013-Jul-24 14:55:43 by pfc:
Not according to the manual:

SlotID: For SMP machines, the integer that identifies the slot.

(Emphasis mine.)

2013-Jul-24 15:55:14 by pfc:
You may be confusing this with the fact that the name "slot" can be redefined (which dates back to the change from vmN to slotN) but that's orthogonal to this issue. No one in the world wants Condor to sort their SlotIds (which are always integers) non-numerically so that 11 comes before 2.

2013-Jul-24 17:55:45 by johnkn:
Yes the SlotID attribute is an integer, but condor_status never looks at that. the default sort is based on 4 keys: OPSYS / ARCH / MACHINE / NAME

Since NAME is what is displayed in the first column, it makes sense to sort by that. I don't think sorting first by OPSYS and ARCH is a good idea, but in most pools, this does no harm. Name usually contains MACHINE so the sort by machine first is just redundant.

if the sort were OPSYS / ARCH / MACHINE / SLOTID, then for machines that have non-default slot names, the result would appear random. Even worse, all dynamic slots have the same SLOTID as their partitionable slot. only the slot name can be used to distinguish them.

I think a lot of other things would have to change about the condor_status display in order for it to make sense to have SlotID be a sort key.

2013-Jul-25 09:51:25 by pfc:
We might be talking past each other: all I'm suggesting is that Name, by virtue of being a composite value of two other attributes (of differing types), is a nonsensical sort key, and that sorting by its two constituent attributes makes more sense. This means sorting by the exact same data in the exact same order, ultimately -- the question is whether you type-convert and smash them together first and then sort by a single type, or sort them independently by their native types before smashing them together into Name. To deal with dynamic slots you just sort by Name after SlotId and there's no issue.

Anyway, I'll make you a deal... ;) We'll poll the crowd next Condor Week and if over 90% of those voting think sorting by Arch, Opsys, Machine, Slotid, Name makes more sense than sorting by Arch, Opsys, Machine, Name (where name is by default the numeric slotid jammed together with the alphanumeric machine), then you agree to implement the fix right after Condor Week. If <=90% agree, I'll buy you a case of beer.

I'll sweeten the deal -- we'll also poll the crowd to see how many people have their pool configured with non-default slot names such that it would affect the sort order above, and if more than one person raises their hand I lose, regardless of the results of other poll. :)

Deal?
